Tweet 1/8
I put a new AI agent, AMP, to a real-world test. The task? Create the ‚ÄúLayouts Concepts‚Äù guide for Air, a brand-new OSS web framework. This meant I had to code examples and write the docs for them. The PR was accepted & merged!
Here‚Äôs how it went. üßµ



The blog post title card for the AMP tool review


Tweet 2/8
The challenge: Air is a new framework currently in alpha. This means it‚Äôs not in any major AI model‚Äôs training data, making it a perfect test for an agent‚Äôs ability to learn from the code I provide in my editor.
Tweet 3/8
To start, I needed to learn the framework myself. I tasked AMP with porting a to-do app I‚Äôd built in another framework (FastHTML) over to Air. I just gave it both projects in my workspace and a prompt. It successfully generated a working app.
Tweet 4/8
Well, almost working. The first version had a bug with database writes. I copied the server logs, fed them back to AMP, and it identified and fixed the issue on the first try. Impressive.



A screenshot showing AMP‚Äôs response after fixing the database error.


Tweet 5/8
With a working app, I understood the layout patterns. Next, I prompted AMP to write the ‚ÄúLayouts Concepts Guide‚Äù based on the code it just helped create.
Tweet 6/8
This is where the ‚Äúhuman in the loop‚Äù part comes in. The first draft was a great start but went way off-scope, adding sections on forms, error pages, etc. My main job was simplification‚Äîdeleting large chunks and refining the code examples.



A screenshot showing the final, clean structure of the documentation that was merged.


Tweet 7/8
The editing process was still way faster than starting from scratch. The final guide was clean, well-structured, and is now part of the official Air documentation.
Tweet 8/8
Final verdict: For the coding task, AMP was a huge win. For documentation, it was helpful but comparable to other top-tier models. The real power was the seamless workflow from code generation to writing.

title: Cursor Tool Review
text: A technical reference for Cursor‚Äôs AI-assisted development features

title: Cursor Tool Review
text:
Tab Completion
Cursor‚Äôs completions use project-wide context rather than just the current file and are very aggressive, which is good in some situations and annoying in others.






Helpful Use Case



I was doing an OSS PR to add type hints to a new web development framework called air (very repetitive task). These needed to be matched up to a HTML reference documentation, and agents kept leaving off or added tags. Cursor‚Äôs tab comletion let me copy/paste from reference docs then hit tab for it to tab complete and modify to python syntax very quickly. It got the pattern after the first couple and let me get through it all in very little time.








Unhelpful Use Case



I was working on creating examples for a workshop I was teaching on FastHTML Syntax and Project Organization. The tab completion was extremely annoying, because it was project wide it kept trying to autocomplete and change my code to what I did somewhere else. I felt like I was fighting the tab completion constantly and having to keep telling it to go away A LOT because I had a very specific thing in mind I wanted to do.

title: Cursor Tool Review
text:
Chat/Agent Interface (Cmd+L Cmd+I)
Context-aware chat that understands project structure. This is pretty helpful with being able to easily reference lots of things with the @ syntax for files. If you have code highlighted when you engage it that will be included in context specifically, and open files will also be in context for you.






Usage Tip



I find it really helpful to dump lots of things in a ref folder then @ like everything useful as I go. This can be tutorials I found online, docs, etc. I can @ the URL directly, but the ref folder serves as an aggregator for me that‚Äôs a bit easier to keep top of mind and curate as needed than the cursor docs feature IMO.


The Agent gives many options and you get really nice diffs that you can individually review, or accept all, and you can restore back to checkpoints if you accepted changes that you find don‚Äôt work well after testing.

title: Cursor Tool Review
text:
Inline Editor (Cmd+K)
Edit code in place with AI assistance Cmd+K. This lets you target specific pieces of code to edit. This is extremely helpful for limiting the scope of AI, especially when it‚Äôs trying to do too much or you know exactly where the change should happen.
I often use this to quickly ask it to write a doc string for documentation, or to do things like refactor a hairy logic stuck iside loops or conditionals into functions.

title: Cursor Tool Review
text:
Terminal helped (also Cmd+K)
In your terminal you can select Cmd+K to have an AI assist that sees that terminals history. This is super helpful for lots of things, like telling you how to run things, git commands you‚Äôve forgotten, telling it to do some curl command you don‚Äôt remember all the flags you need, etc.
The really nice thing about Cmd+K is it‚Äôs very controlled, so it puts the command in your terminal but YOU must run it. This makes it nice because I can ask it to help with even fairly risk things because it won‚Äôt be running anything on it‚Äôs own.

title: Cursor Tool Review
text:
Cursor Rules
Cursor Rules are extremely helpful and there‚Äôs 4 modes:



Cursor Rules Options



Always Apply - Core rules that should never be violated
Apply Manually - Rules you trigger when needed. If you‚Äôre really bad at thinking about context, and you‚Äôre not going to put a lot of effort in then don‚Äôt use this.
Apply Intelligently - This is a great thing to use and provide a good description for the agent to know when to use it.
Apply to Specific Files - File-type or path-specific rules. This can be nice, but you‚Äôre liable to set it to a path, restructure something, then forget and this rule will be acidentally deprecated. This is useful in a decently mature code base, or with very general paths like src or docs directory that are not likely to change.

title: Isaac Flath
text:
LinkedIn Post: AMP Tool Review
Title: Putting AI to the Test: From Code Generation to Documentation with the AMP Agent
I recently ran an experiment to see how a modern AI agent handles a real-world, start-to-finish open-source contribution. I used AMP to create the ‚ÄúLayouts Concepts‚Äù guide for Air, a new web framework. The task was a great test because it required both generating code to understand the framework and then writing the official documentation based on that code.
The results were impressive and highlighted the real strengths (and current limitations) of AI-assisted development.
The Process:

Code Generation: I started by asking AMP to port a to-do application from another framework (FastHTML) to Air. Since Air is in alpha and not in public training data, the agent had to rely entirely on the source code I provided in my workspace. It successfully generated a functional application.
AI-Powered Debugging: The initial app had a bug in the database logic. I simply fed the server logs back into AMP, and it correctly identified and fixed the error on its first attempt.
Documentation Writing: With a working application providing the necessary patterns, I then tasked AMP with writing the concepts guide.

The ‚ÄúHuman in the Loop‚Äù Reality:
While AMP dramatically accelerated the process, it wasn‚Äôt a ‚Äúone-click‚Äù solution. The agent‚Äôs first draft of the documentation was a solid foundation but required significant manual refinement. I had to: - Remove large sections of irrelevant, out-of-scope content that the agent added. - Simplify and consolidate the code examples to make them clearer for educational purposes. - Restructure the narrative to flow logically for a developer audience.
This editing phase was crucial, but it was still far more efficient than writing the entire guide from a blank page.
Final Verdict:
For the coding and debugging portion, AMP was a clear productivity multiplier. For the documentation writing, it provided a strong starting point, comparable to what I‚Äôd expect from other top models like Claude 3 Opus or Gemini 1.5 Pro.
The real win was the seamless end-to-end workflow. The final PR was accepted and merged into the official Air documentation. This experiment shows that with the right approach, AI agents are becoming incredibly powerful tools for tangible software development tasks.
You can read my full, detailed review of the entire process here: [Link to your blog post]

title: Optimize Your Dev Setup For Evals w/ Cursor Rules & MCP
text:
This is a guide to help you optimize your dev setup to get the most out of AI. It‚Äôs showed with specific examples for eval frameworks, but the concepts are universally applicable to any tool. It‚Äôs a guide to help you understand the different layers of context and how to use them to your advantage for your AI tools.
This content was originally created and taught as part of Hamel and Shreya‚Äôs AI Evals Course on Maven (30% off with that link!). If you are building AI tools or products, it‚Äôs a must-take course. Watch the original video here.

title: Optimize Your Dev Setup For Evals w/ Cursor Rules & MCP
text:
1 Why bother?

Better AI assistance
Training cutoff may mean outdated info
Spending time determining what‚Äôs important to your project is good - Forces you to understand your tools better
Make AI better match your taste
Show how AI integrates with your other tools, abstractions, or framework

title: Optimize Your Dev Setup For Evals w/ Cursor Rules & MCP
text:
2 The Three Layers

General Context: Generic tool that works on almost anything

Repomix, GitMCP, etc.

Curated Context: Curated by an expert, such as the tool author

Library provided MCP, llms.txt, etc.

Personalized Context: Context that you can create that‚Äôs unique to your project

Only you can make this and it‚Äôs uniquely tailored to your taste and needs

title: Optimize Your Dev Setup For Evals w/ Cursor Rules & MCP
text:
3 General Context
General context is a good starting point when exploring or unsure about a tool. It‚Äôs generic and not optimized for specific needs. It‚Äôs fast and easy to set up. It‚Äôs useful for quick experimentation and exploration, but it‚Äôs not the best for long-term use. Here‚Äôs a few examples of general context tools.






Good For

Fast and easy to set up
Useful for quick experimentation and exploration




_BraintrustPhoenixInspect





RepoMix is a tool that lets you take a github repo and concatenate all the files based on a pattern into a single file. This is useful for getting lots of context into a single file that you model can easily understand.

3.0.1 Repo Mix



Repo Mix UI for Braintrust






3.0.2 Paste Max
PasteMax is a tool that is a Native App you can install on your machine that lets you concatenate content and files directly in a nice UI. It serves a similar purpose to RepoMix, but it‚Äôs a desktop app and has a different UX that many prefer.
 




3.0.3 Git MCP
GitMCP is a tool that lets you use a github repo as a context source by creating an MCP server to let agents interact with the repo via tools. It‚Äôs a different approach to general context, and it‚Äôs a good way to be able to let agents interact with the repo via tools. It also has a nice web chat interface that‚Äôs great for quick questions to explore the repo.

text:
4 Cursor Rules
Cursor rules let you customize how the curso AI assistance will use your rules, this is extremely helpful and should not be overlooked.

4.1 Rule Creation
You can create rules in the .cursor/rules directory, but there‚Äôs a cursor command that does it for you.



Cursor Rule Creation




4.2 Choosing a Rule Type
Cursor lets you choose a rule type to determine when the models will use the rule context. This is a great way to give a bit more control over model context.



Cursor Rule Types








Rule Application Strategies




Always Apply - Core rules that should never be violated
Apply Manually - Rules you trigger when needed. If you‚Äôre really bad at thinking about context, and you‚Äôre not going to put a lot of effort in then don‚Äôt use this.
Apply Intelligently - This is a great thing to use
Apply to Specific Files - File-type or path-specific rules. This can be nice, but you‚Äôre liable to set it to a path, restructure something, then forget and this rule will be accidentlaly deprecated.

title: Optimize Your Dev Setup For Evals w/ Cursor Rules & MCP
text:
5 Curated Context
Curated context is a good starting point when you want to explore more deeply. It‚Äôs provided by the tool author in some format and it‚Äôs a good way to get a lot of context into a single file that you model can easily understand. This will usually be better than general context, but still not a very tiny investment to set up. However, not every tool or library provides curated context.






Good For




You want to explore more deeply
It‚Äôs provided by the tool author in some format




_BraintrustPhoenixInspectManual Approaches






5.0.0.1 MCP (Model Context Protocol)
Braintrust provides a MCP server that your AI agents can use. This is a lot like GitMCP we saw above, but created by the Braintrust team specifically for Braintrust so it‚Äôs much better.

Official MCP server: https://www.braintrust.dev/docs/reference/mcp
Provides structured access to Braintrust functionality

To set up the MCP server with Cursor, you can use the following settings.



Cursor MCP Settings





Cursor MCP Json






5.0.0.2 LLMs.txt
Phoenix provides an file based in the llms.txt spec format. This is a format that allows for use as static context in a flat file, or as a tool that an MCP server can use to crawl it agentally.

Standard Format for Pheonix: https://arize.com/docs/phoenix/llms.txt
Langchain MCP documentation tool: https://github.com/langchain-ai/mcpdoc





5.0.0.3 llms.txt
For Pheonix, I provided a link to lanchain‚Äôs MCP server that lets you use the llms.txt file as a tool. For Inspect, let‚Äôs use the llms.txt spec to use the flat files as context to see the difference.

Standard format: https://inspect.aisi.org.uk/llms.txt
Full version: https://inspect.aisi.org.uk/llms-full.txt
Individual Pages as Context: https://inspect.aisi.org.uk/index.html.md




Manual curation of context is also a great way to have the most control. There is typically a tradeoff between the amount of time you spend curating the context and the quality of the context. You will get better results if you spend more time carefully curating the context, and whether that payoff is worth the time is dependent on a few things:

How long will you be using this tool and how much? If you use it daily and will for years, it‚Äôs worth the time to curate the context.
How good is the library provided context? If they have carefully curated the context for llms specifically and the tool authors use it themselves, the often it works pretty great out of the box. Sadly, most tools don‚Äôt do this (yet).


5.0.0.4 Jina AI
Jina AI is an easy way to turn any html page into a markdown file. Markdown is much better context for HTML, because there‚Äôs loads of unneccesary noise in the HTML that doesn‚Äôt add value (styling classes, js interactivity, server calls, social media icons, etc.)



5.0.0.5 Copy Outer HTML
By going more manual you can remove the noise and get a more focused context. This is a great way to get a more focused context, but it‚Äôs a more work. The main benefits here over Jina AI is you often can remove lots of unneeded sections like footers, table of contents, sidebars, navigation, etc.
Copying the outer HTML and feeding that into Web2Md is the best workflow I‚Äôve found for this.
